statement.p: On , carefully sketch the graph of f' from the graph of f.

hint.p: What is the slope of the function at every point?

figure.caption: The graph of f(x) (in blue) and f'(x) (in red,dashed).

image.description: A graph on an x–y coordinate plane showing a piecewise linear blue function and its derivative marked in red. The blue graph descends from the left to a low point near (–1, 1), then rises sharply to a peak around (1, 5), and slopes downward again toward the right. Red dashed horizontal segments represent derivative values: a segment around y = –1 from x less than –1 with open circles at boundaries, a segment at y = 2 between –1 and 1 with open circles at x = –1 and x = 1, and a segment at y ≈ –0.5 for x greater than 1 with an open circle at x = 1. The axes include gridlines, labeled x and y.

statement.p: Determine values of f(3) and f'(3) from the graph of f(x) (if they exist).
Do you think f'(1) exists? Defend your answer.

answer.p: It does not exist since the slope radically changes at x=1.

statement.p: Compare the values of \displaystyle \lim_{h \rightarrow 0^-} \frac{f(1+h)-f(1)}{h} and \displaystyle \lim_{h \rightarrow 0^+} \frac{f(1+h)-f(1)}{h}. What does this tell us?

hint.p: To the left of x=1, what is the slope of the function? To the right of x=1?, what is this slope?

answer.p: \displaystyle \lim_{h \rightarrow 0^-} \frac{f(1+h)-f(1)}{h} = 2 and \displaystyle \lim_{h \rightarrow 0^+} \frac{f(1+h)-f(1)}{h} = -0.5. Since these values are different, the two-sided limit \displaystyle \lim_{h \rightarrow 0} \frac{f(1+h)-f(1)}{h} which represents f'(1) does not exist.

statement.p: Write a piecewise function describing f'(x).

p.m: f'(x) = \begin{cases} -1 {\textrm{ if }} -5 < x < -1 \\ 2 {\textrm{ if }} -1 < x < 1 \\ -0.5 {\textrm{ if }} 1 < x < 5 \end{cases}

statement.p: Does f or f' have a larger domain? Will this always be true? Why or why not?

hint.p: What is the domain of f'?

answer.p: The domain of f is [-5,5]. The domain of f' is [-5,-1) \cup (-1,1) \cup (1,5] . So f has the larger domain. This will always be true since the derivative does not exist if the function is not defined at a given point.
